item.title: Google Analytics 4 and Hugo
item.description: So you want to add GA4 to your Hugo website? Here is a step-by-step guide to adding Google Analytics to your Hugo website. Setup a Google Analytics account Head over here and make an account (or sign in if you already have one). Create a property (accessed through admin), add a stream, and point it to your site URL. Once done, head over to admin > property > Data Streams and go to your newly created stream.

item.title: Leetcode 456
item.description: 132 Pattern Head on over here to try the problem for yourself. This one was so annoying :’(. I ended up following this tutorial for ironing out the final cases. Algorithm The goal is to maintain a descending monotonic stack to keep track of the minimum value present before each element in the stack. The ideal case is for the ith index to be as small as possible, the jth index to be as large as possible, and the kth index to be somewhere in between.

item.title: Leetcode 1209
item.description: Remove All Adjacent Duplicates in String II Head on over here to try to the problem for yourself. The problem requires a stack based solution. Algorithm The goal is the find the shortest string possible by removing k duplicated adjacent characters. A simple problem case is illustrated: k = 2 s = "abbac" the result must be c. Iteration 1: remove bb => "aac" Iteration 2: remove aa => "c" The hint points out that instead of maintaining the character count outside the stack, just pass in an object that stores the counter.

item.title: Leetcode 225
item.description: Implementing Stacks Using Queues Head on over here to try the problem for yourself. The solution talks about using 2 queues, which frankly I don’t understand :’). I used a single queue to implement this problem. Algorithm The goal is to implement a stack using the basic queue features provided such as push(), peek() and pop(). The easiest way to implement this is by inserting elements in reverse order. Then the queue will pop the elements like a stack.

item.title: Leetcode 581
item.description: Shortest Unsorted Continuous Subarray Head on over here to try the problem for yourself. I solved this problem using a two-pointer method. Algorithm The goal is to find the points where the array becomes unsorted. We use two loops, one to find the end of the unsorted sub-array and another to find the start of the unsorted sub-array. start = end = -1 as a way to check if they were updated or not during the loops.

item.title: Leetcode 844
item.description: Backspace String Compare Head on over here to try the problem for yourself. There are a few ways discussed in the solutions. I will try to explain the two-pointer method. Algorithm The goal is to try to build the resultant string in one pass. For this reason, we will iterate over the string backwards. If we encounter #, we simply skip the first valid character that follows. Ofcourse, the caveats are considering more backspaces (#) than actual words, in which case we simply get an empty string.
